113460 S2468-8231(23)00543-6 10.1016/j.mcat.2023.113460 Fig. 1 Au-NHC complexes as precursors for supported Au NP catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns of 1 wt% Au/SiO2 prepared from NHC-Au complexes corresponding Table 1. (b), (c) HAADF-STEM images and (d) particle size distribution histogram of 1 wt% Au/SiO2 prepared from [Au(OH)(IPr)]. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TG-DTA profile of [Au(OH)(IPr)] (blue: thermogravimetry, green: differential thermal analysis, red: temperature). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) In situ Au LIII-XANES spectra of [Au(OH)(IPr)]/SiO2 (under 20 mL min−1 H2 and 60 mL min−1 N2 gas mixture, heated 30 to 500°C at a rate of 5°C min−1). (b) Au LIII-XANES spectra of [Au(OH)(IPr)]/SiO2 with the reference of Au foil and Au2O3. (c) Picture of set-up for in situ XAFS. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 CO conversion curves of (a) Au/Al2O3, Au/SiO2, and (b) Au/TiO2. Reaction conditions: 1 vol% CO in air, GHSV 20,000 mL h−1 gcat −1. For (a), ○: [Au(OH)(IPr)]/Al2O3, □: [Au(NTf2)(IPr)]/Al2O3, △: [Au(CH2COCH3)(IPr)]/Al2O3, ⁎: [Au(OH)(IPr)]/SiO2, ●: commercial Au/Al2O3 prepared by deposition-precipitation using HAuCl4. For (b), ○: [Au(OH)(IPr)]/TiO2 (PC-101), □: [Au(OH)(IPr)]/TiO2 (P-25), △: [Au(CH2COCH3)(IPr)]/TiO2 (P-25), ●: commercial Au/TiO3 (P-25) prepared by deposition-precipitation using HAuCl4. Fig. 5 Scheme 1 (a) Cyclization of hex-5-ynoic acid catalyzed by 0.1 mol% Au/SiO2, (b) 0.5 mol% Au/SiO2, and (c) Isomerization of but-3-ene-1,2-diyl diacetate catalyzed by Au/C. The number of runs corresponds to the number of times the catalyst was reused. Scheme 1 Table 1 Preparation of SiO2 supported Au NPs by impregnation followed by calcination a . Gold nanoparticles supported on SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, and carbon (Maxsorb, Ketjen black and Shirasagi New Gold) were prepared by impregnation and solid grinding methods using N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-Au complexes as precursors. A total of nine NHC-Au complex precursors were tested by impregnation and solid grinding method, and [Au(OH)(IPr)] (IPr = 1,3-bis(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)1,3-dihydro-2H-imidazol-2-ylidene) complex led to (1–2 nm) particle sizes by both methods. The prepared catalysts were characterized by XRD (X-ray diffraction), HAADF-STEM (high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy), in situ XAFS (X-ray absorption fine structure), etc. In addition, [Au(OH)(IPr)] and its impregnated [Au(OH)(IPr)]/SiO2 were subjected to TG-DTA (thermogravimetry analysis-differential thermal analysis) and in situ XAFS analysis under calcination conditions, respectively. Moreover, the obtained supported Au nanoparticles (NPs) were effective as catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation, intramolecular cyclization of alkynyl carboxylic acids, and isomerization of allylic esters. Their results suggested that the reduction of [Au(OH)(IPr)] proceeds rapidly from around 300°C, and the residual ligands should be attached to the surface of the Au NPs and protect them from drastic agglutination. These results reveal that properly designed NHC-Au complexes can facilitate the preparation of supported Au NP catalysts with small particle sizes and high activities. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NHC-Au complexes Gold nanoparticles Heterogeneous catalysts Soft Lewis acid catalysts, CO oxidation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The exploration of new loading methods of Au nanoparticles (NPs) onto oxides and other supports is important for the development of new and high-performance catalysts [1] and adsorbents [2]. The preparation of supported Au NPs with a small particle size of less than 5 nm requires proper selection of the precursor, reduction process, and fixation method onto the support [1]. As Okumura et al. have shown in their DFT calculations, the use of precursors containing chloride ions tends to cause aggregation of gold resulting in a large (> 30 nm) size [3]. Therefore, the impregnation method using the most readily available chloroauric acid (HAuCl4_4H2O) proves unsuitable. In the 1980s, Haruta developed deposition-precipitation methods in which chloride-free precursors such as Au(OH)3 are precipitated onto a support by treatment with a base in the liquid phase, setting the stage for the chemistry of supported gold catalysts [4]. This precursor is reduced to Au(0) by calcination or hydrogen treatment and concomitantly fixed on the support in a small Au particle size (< 5 nm). However, while this method is effective for amphoteric and basic supports, it has the disadvantage of not being applicable to acidic supports such as silica and zeolite due to electrostatic repulsion. Subsequently, several chloride-free precursors and methods were developed that are applicable to a wide range of supports. Louis et al. developed an incipient wetness impregnation method using HAuCl4 followed by an ammonia treatment [5]. Sakurai et al. reported Au(OAc)3 as an impregnation precursor, but it had low solubility and required the use of a rather dilute solution [6]. Some of these authors (Murayama et. al.) have developed a Au (III)-β-alanine complex as an impregnation precursor with excellent water solubility and supported Au(0) NPs with a particle size of less than 3 nm on SiO2, TiO2, Ketchen black, etc [7]. Besides, some of the authors (Ishida et. al.) reported that dimethyl(2,4-pentanedionato)gold(III) (Me2Au(acac)) was an excellent precursor for solid-phase grinding methods [8]. This method has the advantage that the precursors can be loaded by simple physical mixing. Recently, (5-methyl-2-(pyridin-2-yl)phenyl)bis(trifluoroacetato)gold(III) (AuTFA) was also developed as an excellent precursor for the solid grinding method [9]. Using this precursor, Al2O3 and TiO2 can be loaded with Au NPs having sizes of less than 3 nm. In the case of SiO2, an acidic support, the size of Au NPs was 7.3 nm, but treatment with KO t Bu effectively reduced the size to 2.2 nm. N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) have been used as ligands for homogeneous metal catalysts [10a-c] and have also received attention as precursors and stabilizers of Au NPs [10d,e] because of their ability to form strong covalent bonds to single and nanoparticle metals. The first report of its kind appeared in 2005 for Ir [11] and in 2009 for Au [12a]. Tilley et al. obtained colloidal Au NPs by reduction of NHC-Au complexes with KBEt3H or 9-borabicyclo[3.3.1]nonane (9-BBN) in the liquid phase. Guari and Monge also prepared colloidal Au NPs by thermolysis of NHC-Au complexes, which were successfully fixed onto a silica modified with aminopropyl groups [12b]. The particle size of Au before fixation was small, less than 2 nm, but after loading onto silica, a slight increase was observed in the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image, although the authors did not calculate it. There are several other examples of preparing Au NPs from mononuclear NHC-Au complexes, but there are few examples of supporting them onto a support and applying them to catalysis [10]. On the other hand, top-down approach to forming nanoparticles followed by NHC coordination is possible because of their strong coordination ability. Glorius and Ravoo have reported on the formation of Au-Pd-alloy stabilized by NHC supported on TiO2 and examined catalytic hydrogenation using these materials [12c]. García and Mata investigated the effects of NHC ligands in the stabilization of Au NPs anchored onto the surface of graphene and tested their catalytic performance through hydration and intramolecular hydroamination of alkynes [12d]. In this contribution, we describe the preparation of supported Au NPs (particle sizes below 2 nm) onto SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, carbon (Maxsorb, Ketjen Black and Shirasagi New Gold) by impregnation and solid grinding methods using NHC-Au complexes as precursors (Fig. 1 ). The effects of the ancillary ligand (NHC) and the anion are examined. The obtained supported Au NPs were effective as catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation, intramolecular cyclization of alkynyl carboxylic acids, and isomerization of allylic esters. These catalysts were characterized by XRD (X-ray diffraction), HAADF-STEM (high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy), XAFS (X-ray absorption fine structure), etc. In addition, [Au(OH)(IPr)] (IPr = (1,3-bis(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)1,3-dihydro-2H-imidazol-2-ylidene)) and its impregnated [Au(OH)(IPr)]/SiO2 were subjected to TG-DTA (thermogravimetry analysis-differential thermal analysis) and in situ XAFS analysis under calcination conditions, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials HAuCl4·4H2O was purchased from Tanaka Kikinzoku Kogyo K.K. Hex-5-ynoic acid was supplied by FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corp. [Au(Cl)(IPr)], [Au(NTf2)(IPr)], and but-3-ene-1,2-diyl diacetate were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Hex-5-ynoic acid was purified by distillation before reaction, while other reagents were used as received. SiO2 (CARiACT Q-10 and Q-15, 60 μm, specific surface area of 300 and 200 m2 g−1), TiO2 (P-25, 50 m2 g−1), activated carbon (Maxsorb MSC-30, Ketjen black (EC300J), and Shirasagi New Gold were respectively provided by Fuji Silysia Chemical Ltd., Nippon Aerosil Co., Ltd., Kansai Coke & Chemicals Co., Ltd., Lion Specialty Chemicals Co., Ltd. and Mitsubishi Corporation Life Sciences Ltd. TiO2 (anatase) (PC-101, 340 m2·g−1) and Al2O3 (AKP-G015, 148 m2·g−1) were supplied by Titan Kogyo Ltd. and Sumitomo Chemical Co., respectively. Commercial Au/SiO2, Al2O3, and Au/TiO2 were purchased from Haruta Gold Inc. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of Au-NHC complexes [Au(OH)(IPr)], [Au(Ph)(IPr)] (Ph = 4-methoxyphenyl), [Au(Cbz)(IPr)] (Cbz = 9H-carbazol-9-yl), [Au(CCPh)(ItBu)] (ItBu = 1,3-di-tert-butyl-1,3-dihydro-2H-imidazol-2-ylidene), [Au(Ph)(IAd)] (IAd = 1,3-di(adamantan-1-yl)-1,3-dihydro-2H-imidazol-2-ylidene) and [Au(CH2COCH3)(IPr)] were synthesized according to known procedures [13]. Purification of compounds by filtration was performed using basic alumina or celite purchased from Sigma Aldrich, or syringe membrane filters purchased from Carl Roth. Unless otherwise noted, absolute ethanol and freshly crushed, anhydrous bases were used. When handling acid-sensitive gold complexes, all chlorinated solvents (including the deuterated ones) were neutralized prior to use by filtration through dried basic alumina. 2.2.2 Synthesis of (1,3-dicyclohexyl-1,3-dihydro-2H-imidazol-2-ylidene)(phenylethynyl)gold [Au(CCPh)(ICy)] A vial equipped with a magnetic stirring bar and a septum-equipped screw-cap, was charged under air with 120 mg of [Au(ICy)Cl] (0.258 mmol), 107 mg of K2CO3 (0.774 mmol, 3 equiv.) and the solids were suspended in ethanol (1.0 mL). Phenylacetylene (0.516 mmol, 2 equiv., 52.7 mg, 56.7 μL) was added with a micropipette. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 16 hours. After this time the solvent was removed in vacuo and THF was added (4 mL). The mixture was filtered through a syringe membrane filter and a 2 cm celite plug, the solvent was evaporated under vacuum and the resulting solid was washed with pentane (3 × 3 mL). The white solid was further purified by filtration through basic alumina (4 cm plug) with benzene (5 mL). The solvent was evaporated to dryness under vacuum to give a white oil. Pentane (5 mL) was added and refluxed until a white solid was obtained. Then the mixture was filtered on a frit using an additional amount of pentane (5 mL) and the desired compound was obtained as a white solid in 58% yield (80.0 mg, 0.151 mmol) after drying under vacuum. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD2Cl2) δ (ppm) = 7.39 – 7.35 (m, 2H, HAr), 7.26 – 7.21 (m, 2H, HAr), 7.19 – 7.14 (m, 1H, HAr), 6.99 (s, 2H, NCH Imid), 4.61 (tt, J = 11.9, 3.9 Hz, 2H, NCHCy), 2.10 (app dd, J = 12.3, 1.7 Hz, 4H, CH2), 1.92 – 1.85 (m, 4H, CH2), 1.80 – 1.70 (m, 2H, CH2), 1.62 (m, 4H, CH2), 1.56 – 1.44 (m, 4H, CH2), 1.31 – 1.15 (m, 2H, CH2). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CD2Cl2) δ (ppm) = 185.5 (CICy-Au), 132.4 (CHAr), 131.7 (CAr), 128.5 (CHAr), 127.0 (AuCCPh), 126.5 (CHAr), 117.7 (NCHImid), 104.6 (AuCCPh), 61.1 (N-CHCy), 34.8 (CH2), 26.0 (CH2), 25.8 (CH2). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for C23H29AuN2: C 52.08, H 5.51, N 5.28; found: C 52.58, H 5.68, N 5.64. 2.2.3 Preparation of supported Au NP catalysts by an impregnation method A precursor NHC-Au complex (2.5 mg Au) was dissolved in 0.25 mL of tetrahydrofuran (THF) and 0.05 mL of water. Support (247.5 mg) was added to the solution, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature. After impregnation, the solid was calcined in air or a mixed gas of H2 and N2. The heating rate was kept 5°C min−1 until the target temperature and then the temperature was kept 30 min. 2.2.4 Preparation of supported Au NP catalysts by a solid grinding method Support (500 mg) and the Au complex (5.0 mg Au) were ground in an agate mortar in air at room temperature for 20 min, followed by calcination in air at 300°C for 2 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The content of Au in the synthesized complex and yield of Au were calculated by the concentration of aqueous solution measured by Agilent 4100 MP-AES (Agilent Technologies). The complex (5 mg) was dissolved in 50 g of water, and this solution (10 g) was added to 50 g of water. Thermal decomposition profiles of Au complexes were obtained by TG-DTA on TG/DTA7300 (Hitachi High-Tech Science Corporation). XRD data were collected on a MiniFlex600 (Rigaku Co.) diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The scanning rate was 2° min−1 or 10° min−1 and the scanning step was 0.01° in 2θ ranging from 10–90°. HAADF-STEM images were acquired with a JEOL JEM-ARM200F NEOARM and a JEM-3200FS operated at 200 and 300 kV, respectively. Au LIII-edge XAFS spectra were collected at the BL14B2 beamline of SPring-8 (Hyogo, Japan). Synchrotron radiation from the storage ring was monochromated by a Si(311) double-crystal. The experiments were conducted in the transmission mode at room temperature. The XAFS spectra were analyzed by using the program REX2000 (Rigaku Co.) and Athena. In situ XAFS spectra were also collected using the same optical system with the XAFS measurements during the calcination process of preparing the supported Au NPs. The sample was heated from room temperature to 300°C or 500°C at 5°C min −1 under air. The collection of the XAFS spectrum required approximately 3.5 min. 1H, 13C-{1H} Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 400 Ultrashield spectrometer at 298 K using the residual solvent peak as reference (CD2Cl2: δH = 5.32 ppm, δC = 54.00 ppm). Peaks are assigned as: s (singlet), d (doublet), app d (apparent doublet), t (triplet), tt (triplet of triplets), h (heptuplet) and m (multiplet). 2.4 Cyclization of hex-5-ynoic acid In the experiments described in Scheme 1 (a), a screw cap vial with a magnetic stirring bar was charged with 1 wt% Au/SiO2 (19.7 mg, 0.1 mol%) prepared from [Au(OH)(IPr)] or [Au(Ph)(IAd)]. Then, dichloromethane (2 mL) and hex-5-ynoic acid (1 mmol) were added under N2 flow. The reaction tube was sealed, and the mixture was stirred at 50°C for 5 h. After the reaction, the mixture was cooled and centrifuged. The supernatant of the reaction mixture was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy after the addition of mesitylene as the internal standard. For recycle experiments, the used catalyst was washed twice with Et2O and dried under vacuum for 3 h before the next cycle of reuse. In the experiments in Scheme 1 (b), 0.5 mol% catalyst prepared from [Au(Cbz)(IPr)] was used in the presence of 5 mol% NaOH and the reaction time was 3 h, and before the fifth run, the recovered catalyst was calcined in air at 300°C for 30 min. 2.5 Isomerization reaction of but-3-ene-1,2-diyl diacetate A screw cap vial was charged with 1 wt% Au/C (49.3 mg, 0.25 mol%) prepared from [Au(OH)(IPr)], but-3-ene-1,2-diyl diacetate (1 mmol), and a magnetic stirring bar. Then the reaction mixture was stirred at 150°C. The mixture was filtered after the reaction, and the filtrate was analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) with an Agilent GC6850 Series II instrument equipped with a flame ionization detector and a J&W HP-1 column using tridecane as an internal standard. In a reusing experiment, the same procedure was repeated. After each run, the catalysts were washed with Et2O and dried under a vacuum condition for 3 h. 2.6 General procedures for the CO oxidation Catalytic tests for CO oxidation were performed in a fixed-bed glass reactor (internal diameter of 6 mm), containing 0.15 g of catalyst. Pretreatment was carried out in a stream of air at 250°C for 1 h at a flow rate of 50 mL min−1. Then, the catalyst was cooled to room temperature, and the reaction gas (1 vol% CO in air) was passed through the reactor at a flow rate of 50 mL min−1 (weight hour space velocity, WHSV = 20,000 mL h−1 gcat −1). The outlet gas was analyzed by an online GC (Ohkura Riken, model 802 or Shimadzu, GC-8 A equipped with Gasukuropack 54 and molecular sieve 13X columns). CO2 production was also measured by the same GC analysis described above. CO2 selectivity was almost 100%. The moisture content in the reaction gas was monitored by a dew point meter (Air Liquid DPO-6), and the water concentrations were in the range of 20–200 ppm. We used T1/2, which is the temperature at 50% CO conversion, to evaluate the catalytic activity. 3 Results and discussion The impregnation method employing the NHC-Au complexes was investigated for SiO2 and carbon as support. Since the solubility of the NHC-Au complexes in water was poor, THF/water was used as a solvent and stirred for 30 min. Since the impregnation was carried out with a minimal amount of solvent, the incipient wetness method, the solvent was almost completely evaporated during the stirring process. After impregnation, the solid was calcined in air. The heating rate was kept at 5°C min−1 from room temperature to 300°C and then kept at this elevated temperature for 30 min. The sizes of the formed Au NPs were roughly evaluated by the crystalline size which could be determined by XRD according to the Scherrer equation with the full width at half the maximum value of the Au(111) diffraction peak at 38.2° (Fig. 2 a). When [AuCl(IPr)] was used as precursor, the crystalline size of the Au NPs was 7.0 nm as estimated from the XRD data, but when [Au(OH)(IPr)] was used, the NPs size decreased to less than 2 nm. (Table 1 , entries 1 and 2). The existence of chloride ions should cause an increase in particle size. The reason for the significant noise of XRD with [AuCl(IPr)] is probably due to incomplete reduction of Au(I). When [Au(Ph)(IPr)] and [Au(Cbz)(IPr)] complexes which contain no chloride ion were used as precursors, the crystalline sizes were below 4 nm (entries 3 and 4). The crystalline sizes of the supported Au NPs prepared from the other target complexes with NHC ligands other than IPr increased to more than 7 nm (entries 5–7). These results suggest that the complexes with IPr ligands are suitable precursors for the preparation of supported Au NPs, and [Au(OH)(IPr)] provides an interesting candidate for catalytic applications due to the relatively simple structure and small particle size. Next, the effect of calcination temperature was explored. A sharp increase in the crystalline size was observed when the calcination temperature was just increased to 320°C or 350°C (entries 8 and 9). Moreover, hydrogen stream conditions were examined as reduction conditions, which can reduce the gold precursors at lower temperatures. Using [Au(OH)(IPr)] as a precursor, when the flow rate was H2: 20 mL min−1 and N2: 60 mL min−1, a crystalline size of 6.7 nm was obtained (entry 10). When only hydrogen (30 mL min−1) was used under the same condition, the crystalline size was found to be 8.3 nm (entry 11). Furthermore, the performance of [Au(OH)(IPr)] for preparing activated carbon-supported Au NPs was also investigated, and a small crystalline size of 4.5 nm was obtained (entry 12), showing its universality on support materials. Normally, it is difficult to determine the specific particle sizes by XRD when the crystalline sizes are below 2 nm, for their peaks are usually too broad to be recognized. Therefore, the particle size and morphology of supported Au NPs on SiO2 prepared from [Au(OH)(IPr)] (Table 1, entry 2) was examined by HAADF-STEM. Au NPs with an average particle size of 1.0 ± 0.6 nm were uniformly loaded onto SiO2 (Fig. 2b). This result proved to be in good agreement with the XRD results. TG-DTA of [Au(OH)(IPr)] was carried out by raising the temperature from room temperature to 500°C at a rate of 5°C min−1 and then holding it at 500°C for 30 min (Fig. 3 ). The decrease in mass in the first step (80 to 100°C) was attributable to the H2O evaporation contained in the complex, and the decrease in mass in the second step (250°C to 500°C) was due to the ligand decomposition of the complex. This result indicated that the decomposition of the ligands continued to 500°C, suggesting that the Au/SiO2 prepared by 300°C calcination still contained some undecomposed ligands. On the other hand, when the calcination temperature is higher than 300°C, the size of Au NPs tends to increase, and it seems to be difficult to remove all the NHC-derived organic components while keeping the particle size small. This result suggested that the reduction is somewhat insufficient at 300°C, and that residual ligand is most likely still attached to the surface of the Au NPs and that it inhibits drastic agglutination. Additionally, in situ XAFS measurements were performed to investigate the reduction property of the supported Au species during the calcination process under hydrogen stream (Fig. 4 c), in which SiO2 impregnated with [Au(OH)(IPr)] dissolved in THF {[Au(OH)(IPr)]/SiO2} was continuously heated up to 500°C at a rate of 5°C min−1. The measurements were carried out under a gas mixture of 20 mL min−1 H2 and 60 mL min−1 N2. From the in situ X-ray absorption near edge spectra (XANES) data, a slight change occurred by comparing the intensities of the white line from 265°C, and then a further change could be observed from 283°C to 301°C (Fig. 4a). The spectra at 411°C and re R.T. (after cooling to room temperature) are consistent and correspond to zero-valent Au species (Fig. 4b). This indicates that the reduction of [Au(OH)(IPr)] proceeds rapidly from 283°C to 301°C, and is completed at 411°C. The catalytic activity of the obtained supported Au NPs was examined. Here, two liquid-phase reactions in which supported Au NPs act as soft Lewis acids to activate the π-electrons of alkenes and alkynes were tested, and both of these scenarios the systems show high atomic efficiency. [14,15]. The cyclization of hex-5-ynoic acid with 0.1 mol% Au/SiO2 afforded the product in > 99% yield both in the first and the second run, but the yield was decreased to 50% in the third run. (Scheme 1(a)). To improve the recyclability of the catalyst, the amount of the catalyst was increased to 0.5 mol%, but the yield dropped to 52% after the fourth run (Scheme 1 (b)). The catalytic activity was not recovered by calcination at 300°C for 30 minutes (Scheme 1 (b), run 5). The catalysts used in these experiments were entries 2 and 4 of Table 1, both of which gave good yields as the Au particle size was smaller than 2 nm. When this reaction was performed with the 8.6 nm Au catalyst (entry 7 of Table 1), the yield dropped to 6% (Scheme 1 (a)). We have reported that the catalytic activity of this reaction is inversely proportional to the gold particle size of Au/ZrO2 catalysts [14], but the difference in catalytic activity in this case seems quite larger. Perhaps this is because the Au-Ph bonds in the precursor are difficult to decompose under the calcination conditions and remain intact or as soot in the final samples. An allylic ester isomerization reaction of but-3-ene-1,2-diyl diacetate (3,4-DABE) into but-2-ene-1,4-diyl diacetate (1,4-DABE) was also investigated (Scheme 1b). Good yields and reusability were obtained when compared with previous results [15]. The solid grinding method was examined with several NHC-Au complex precursors and supports (Table 2 ). In a previous report, we have presented that a non-volatile precursor, Au-TFA, can be an excellent precursor as can the volatile precursor, Me2Au(acac) [9]. Therefore, the non-volatility of the NHC-Au complex is also not considered to be a problem. When [Au(OH)(IPr)] was used as a precursor, 7.0, 1.4, and 3.0 nm Au NPs were obtained on SiO2, Al2O3, and TiO2, respectively (Table 2, entries 1, 2 and 3, Fig. S1 (a) and (b)). Ketjen black (Carbon) could be loaded with 30 wt% gold with a particle size of 6.8 nm for application in electrode materials (Table 2, entry 4, Fig. S1 (c)). A Au(IPr) complex bearing bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide anion ([Au(NTf2)(IPr)]) also permitted to prepare Au NPs on Al2O3 with an average particle size of 1.4 nm (Table 2, entry 5, Fig. S1 (d)). The Au(IPr) complex with the 2-oxopropyl ligand ([Au(CH2COCH3)(IPr)]) was also effective, and Au NPs with the average particle sizes of 5.2, 1.3, and 9.3 nm could be supported on SiO2, Al2O3, and TiO2, respectively (Table 2, entries 6, 7 and 8, Fig. S1 (e), (f) and (g)). The catalytic activity of the obtained catalysts was evaluated by CO oxidation (Fig. 5 ), and T 1/2, the temperature where the CO conversion reaches 50%, are shown in Table 2. It is widely accepted that Au-catalyzed CO oxidation takes place at the perimeter interface between Au and metal oxide (MOx) supports [1b]. Au and MOx are responsible for the adsorption of CO and activation of O2, respectively. Therefore, it has been reported that the amount of cationic Au species and catalytic activity did not directly correlate [16]. On the other hand, the deposition of Au as much as small particles is beneficial for an increase in the Au–MOx interface, and the selection of suitable MOx supports to activate O2 at the oxygen vacancy sites of MOx surface. Au/SiO2 prepared using [Au(OH)(IPr)] showed low activity due to a large Au particle size and to a lack of oxygen vacancies (Table 2, entry 1, Fig. 5a); commercial Au/SiO2 prepared by the conventional preparation method using Au(en)2Cl3 (en: ethylenediamine) also shows low activity (24% conversion at 300°C) (Table 2, entry 9). Au/Al2O3 prepared using [Au(OH)(IPr)] (Table 2, entry 2) and [Au(CH2COCH3)(IPr)] (Table 2, entry 7) exhibited better catalytic activity than the commercial Au/Al2O3 prepared using HAuCl4 (Table 2, entry 10), while Au/Al2O3 prepared using [Au(NTf2)(IPr)] decreased catalytic activity largely (Table 2, entry 5) despite the small Au particle size (Fig. 5a). It is likely that the decomposition of NTf2 ligand needs higher temperature than the IPr ligand and that the ligand residue remained on the Au surface, which inhibits the CO oxidation. The commercial Au/TiO2 (P-25) (Au 4.1±2.2 nm) recorded T 1/2 of 7°C, but Au/TiO2 (P-25) prepared using [Au(CH2COCH3)(IPr)] showed low activity due to large Au particle size (Table 2, entry 8). Given that [Au(OH)(IPr)] and [Au(CH2COCH3)(IPr)] gave similar Au particle size on the same supports (SiO2 and Al2O3, respectively), the difference in the Au particle size for Au/TiO2 was ascribed to the difference in specific surface area of TiO2. P-25 contains anatase as a major component (75%) with rutile, and have a specific surface area of ca. 50 m2 g−1, while PC-101 contains only anatase and have a specific surface area of ca. 340 m2 g−1. Therefore, TiO2 having high specific surface area is more suitable to deposit Au as small nanoparticles. Once small Au nanoparticles were stabilized on TiO2 (PC-101) having oxygen vacancies on the surface (Table 2, entry 3), the catalysts exhibited superior catalytic activity to the commercial Au/TiO2 (Fig. 5b and Table 2, entry 11). Therefore, surface Au atoms and the Au–MOx interface would be sufficiently exposed, resulting in almost negligible effect of the ligand residue for CO oxidation in the case of [Au(OH)(IPr)] and [Au(CH2COCH3)(IPr)]. From these results, Au-NHC complexes, in particular for [Au(OH)(IPr)] and [Au(CH2COCH3)(IPr)] can work as promising precursors in the SG method. 4 Conclusion We have successfully prepared supported Au NPs (particle sizes below 2 nm) on SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, and carbon (Maxsorb, Ketjen Black and Shirasagi New Gold) by impregnation and solid grinding methods using NHC-Au complexes as precursors. A total of nine NHC-Au complex precursors were tested by impregnation and solid grinding methods, and [Au(OH)(IPr)] complex showed great results in both methods. In addition, [Au(OH)(IPr)] and its impregnated [Au(OH)(IPr)]/SiO2 were subjected to TG-DTA and in situ XAFS analysis under calcination conditions, respectively. Their results suggested that the reduction of [Au(OH)(IPr)] proceeds rapidly from around 300°C, and the residual ligands are most likely attached to the surface of the Au NPs and protect them from agglutination. Moreover, the obtained supported Au NPs were effective as catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation, intramolecular cyclization of alkynyl carboxylic acids, and isomerization of allylic esters. We believe that these results clearly evidence the role of ligands in preparing supported Au NP catalysts with small particle sizes and high activities, and this may help to broaden the application range of heterogeneous gold catalysts and their performance in the future. coredata.dc:description: Gold nanoparticles supported on SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, and carbon (Maxsorb, Ketjen black and Shirasagi New Gold) were prepared by impregnation and solid grinding methods using N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-Au complexes as precursors. A total of nine NHC-Au complex precursors were tested by impregnation and solid grinding method, and [Au(OH)(IPr)] (IPr = 1,3-bis(2,6-diisopropylphenyl)1,3-dihydro-2H-imidazol-2-ylidene) complex led to (1–2 nm) particle sizes by both methods. The prepared catalysts were characterized by XRD (X-ray diffraction), HAADF-STEM (high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy), in situ XAFS (X-ray absorption fine structure), etc. In addition, [Au(OH)(IPr)] and its impregnated [Au(OH)(IPr)]/SiO2 were subjected to TG-DTA (thermogravimetry analysis-differential thermal analysis) and in situ XAFS analysis under calcination conditions, respectively. Moreover, the obtained supported Au nanoparticles (NPs) were effective as catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation, intramolecular cyclization of alkynyl carboxylic acids, and isomerization of allylic esters. Their results suggested that the reduction of [Au(OH)(IPr)] proceeds rapidly from around 300°C, and the residual ligands should be attached to the surface of the Au NPs and protect them from drastic agglutination. These results reveal that properly designed NHC-Au complexes can facilitate the preparation of supported Au NP catalysts with small particle sizes and high activities.
coredata.dc:title: Supported gold nanoparticles prepared from NHC-Au complex precursors as reusable heterogeneous catalysts
